summary: This is a General Release agreement from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program (EVCP), signed by a claimant on October 3, 2020, accepting a compensation offer in exchange for releasing a broad range of individuals and entities associated with Jeffrey Epstein's estate from all claims related to his sexual abuse. The document outlines the terms of the release, confidentiality provisions, and lien resolution procedures.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: The deceased individual whose estate and associated entities are being released from claims by the victim signing this agreement. He is identified as the perpetrator of the sexual abuse.

persons.name: Claimant
persons.context: An unnamed individual who submitted a claim to the EVCP, was determined eligible, accepted a compensation offer, and is signing this release to waive claims against Epstein's estate and associates.

persons.name: Administrator
persons.context: The official who runs the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, determines eligibility, issues compensation offers, and maintains claimant confidentiality.

connections.description: The claimant asserts she is a victim of sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein, as stated in the document's preamble.
The Administrator reviewed the claimant's submissions, determined her eligibility for the EVCP, and issued the compensation offer she accepted.

events.title: Execution of EVCP General Release
events.description: A claimant signs a General Release agreement with the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, accepting a financial offer and releasing Epstein's estate and a wide network of associates from all claims.

keyFacts: The document is a broad legal release where a victim accepts compensation from the EVCP and waives all claims against Jeffrey Epstein's estate, its trustees, and a vast network of associated individuals and entities (collectively 'Releasees').

The release explicitly covers claims arising from sexual abuse by Epstein and applies to claims under 'claims revival statutes' enacted in several U.S. jurisdictions, which revive time-barred sexual abuse claims.
The claimant waives rights under California Civil Code Section 1542 and similar laws, meaning she releases even unknown or unsuspected claims that might have affected her decision to settle.

The EVCP Administrator uses Garretson Resolution Group, Inc. (Epiq) to resolve any Medicare/Medicaid liens related to the compensation, with the Epstein Estate paying any negotiated lien amount in addition to the victim's compensation offer.
The release does not require the claimant to maintain confidentiality about her claim or the compensation process, though the Administrator maintains confidentiality of claimant information.
